cheatsheetvideos.quote: David Got help for his Class M using our Cheat sheet!
Jose explains how the motorcycle cheat sheet helped him pass his written exam.

questions.question: After entering a turn, you should roll on the throttle and:
questions.answerA: Always slow down.
questions.answerB: Maintain a steady speed or accelerate gradually.
questions.answerC: Accelerate drastically.
questions.answerD: Not worry about your speed.
questions.explanation: Roll on the throttle through a turn to stabilize your suspension. Maintain a steady speed or accelerate gradually through the turn.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: It is a good idea to drag your feet.
questions.answerB: Your toes should be pointed downward.
questions.answerC: You should keep your feet firmly on the footrests.
questions.answerD: You should try to keep your feet away from the controls.
questions.explanation: To maintain proper balance, your feet should be placed firmly on the footrests and not dragged on the ground. Do not point your toes downward, as this may cause them to catch on the road. Keep your feet near the controls so you can reach them quickly, if needed.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride under the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and brakes.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Accelerate before turning.
questions.explanation: When approaching a potentially dangerous area, such as an intersection, you should cover the clutch lever and both brakes in order to reduce the amount of time you will need to react to any hazards.

questions.question: The gearshift lever is operated by:
questions.answerA: Your right hand.
questions.answerB: Your right foot.
questions.answerC: Your left hand.
questions.answerD: Your left foot.
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever of a motorcycle is located in front of the left footrest and is operated by the rider's left foot.

questions.question: When crossing angled railroad tracks, it is usually safest to approach the tracks:
questions.answerA: By proceeding straight within your lane.
questions.answerB: At a 45-degree angle.
questions.answerC: At a 90-degree angle.
questions.answerD: At a fast speed.
questions.explanation: In general, it is safest to simply proceed straight in your lane when crossing angled railroad tracks. Turning to approach tracks at a right angle can be dangerous because it may send you traveling into another lane.

questions.question: One way to tell if your rear tire has gone flat while riding is if:
questions.answerA: There is a hissing noise coming from the rear of the bike.
questions.answerB: The back end is jerking from side to side.
questions.answerC: You are unable to accelerate.
questions.answerD: The rear brake does not work.
questions.explanation: If your rear tire fails, the back of your motorcycle will likely jerk from side to side. It is rare for motorcyclists to actually hear a tire fail.

questions.question: Before riding, check all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Your tires' inflation pressure.
questions.answerB: The amount of tread on your tires.
questions.answerC: The reflective quality of your tires.
questions.answerD: The general condition of the sidewalls on your tires.
questions.explanation: Before every ride, be sure to check your tires' inflation pressure, your tires' treadwear, and the general condition of the sidewalls and tread surface on the tires.

questions.question: If you must ride over an obstacle, you should:
questions.answerA: Decrease your speed as much as possible.
questions.answerB: Lean the motorcycle to one side.
questions.answerC: Speed up, if possible.
questions.answerD: Stay on your seat and remove your feet from the footrests.
questions.explanation: If you are unable avoid an obstacle and must instead ride over it, slow down and approach the obstacle at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Keep your motorcycle straight up and down, if possible. Just before contact, roll off the throttle slightly to lighten the front end of the motorcycle.

questions.question: When riding in a group, it is best to put inexperienced riders near the front because:
questions.answerA: Experienced riders can more easily keep an eye on them.
questions.answerB: They will get lost if they are leading.
questions.answerC: They may slow the group down as the leaders.
questions.answerD: They will ride too fast in any other position.
questions.explanation: In a group, less experienced riders should ride toward the front, just behind the leader, so more experienced riders can easily watch them.

questions.question: Signals on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Serve little purpose since motorcycles are smaller than most other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are very important to alert other motorists to a rider's intentions.
questions.answerC: Should not be used if no vehicles are close to the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Are more complicated than those on a car.
questions.explanation: You are especially vulnerable as a motorcyclist, so it is very important to use your turn signals to alert others to your intentions. Always use them any time that you plan to change lanes or turn, even if you don't think anyone else is nearby.

questions.question: If you are riding in traffic when a small animal enters your lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Do whatever you can, including swerving into other lanes, to avoid hitting the animal.
questions.answerB: Switch lanes as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Stay in your lane.
questions.answerD: Flash your lights to try to scare the animal.
questions.explanation: Do everything you safely can to avoid hitting an animal in the road. If you are in traffic, however, you should remain in your lane. Swerving into another lane of traffic to avoid hitting an animal can cause you to collide with another driver. Hitting something small is less dangerous than hitting something big.

questions.question: Rain suits:
questions.answerA: Should not be used.
questions.answerB: Should not balloon when riding.
questions.answerC: Are not needed since motorcycles shouldn't be operated in the rain.
questions.answerD: Should tear easily.
questions.explanation: High-quality rain suits designed for motorcycle riding will resist tearing and ballooning when a rider travels at high speeds.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should ride:
questions.answerA: In the front of the group.
questions.answerB: Right behind the leader.
questions.answerC: At the back of the group.
questions.answerD: Wherever they are most comfortable.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should ride just behind the leader near the front of the group. This allows more experienced riders to keep an eye on them from the back of the group.

questions.question: Riding between two vehicles moving in the same direction:
questions.answerA: Is illegal.
questions.answerB: Is encouraged if traffic is heavy.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged during the day to prevent traffic jams.
questions.answerD: Is acceptable if the motorcyclist is comfortable with the move.
questions.explanation: In Oregon, it is illegal for motorcycles and mopeds to pass between two moving vehicles on a multilane highway or one-way street.

questions.question: If your motorcycle starts to wobble, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Downshift.
questions.answerB: Accelerate.
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and close the throttle gradually.
questions.answerD: Gradually apply your brakes.
questions.explanation: Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble because doing so will only make the motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down by gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as possible, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Avoid applying the brakes, as this may also worsen the wobble.

questions.question: When you are riding on a bridge grating, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride on the far right side of the lane.
questions.answerB: Always ride on the far left side of the lane.
questions.answerC: Slowly zigzag across the grating.
questions.answerD: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the surface.
questions.explanation: Crossing rain grooves or bridge gratings may cause your motorcycle to move in a weaving motion. This is usually not dangerous, so simply relax and proceed across the surface at a steady speed. Trying to ride at an angle to compensate for the weave is dangerous because it forces you to zigzag to stay in your lane.

questions.question: All of the following will lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, except:
questions.answerA: Remaining alert.
questions.answerB: Identifying hazards and prioritizing risks.
questions.answerC: Riding without a headlight.
questions.answerD: Maintaining a space cushion.
questions.explanation: To reduce your risk of being involved in a crash, you should remain alert and ready to react to any hazard. Identify hazards and decide the order in which you need to address the hazards. Always use your headlight to make yourself more visible and maintain an adequate space cushion around your motorcycle at all times.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Squeeze the front brake and press the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Grab at the front brake and squeeze the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Jam on the front brake and grab at the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Press down on the front brake and jam on the rear brake.
questions.explanation: To brake, squeeze the front brake lever and press down on the rear brake pedal. Always use both brakes when slowing or stopping.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to wobble, you should:
questions.answerA: Accelerate out of the wobble.
questions.answerB: Use the brakes gradually.
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and close the throttle gradually.
questions.answerD: Downshift.
questions.explanation: Trying to accelerate out of a wobble is dangerous and will only make your motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly (without trying to fight the wobble), gradually close the throttle to slow down, and move your weight as far forward and downward as possible. Pull off the road as soon as you can.

questions.question: It is difficult for other motorists to see motorcycles at night. To make up for that, a motorcycle rider should:
questions.answerA: Reduce their speed when riding at night.
questions.answerB: Sound their horn repeatedly when riding at night.
questions.answerC: Not ride at night.
questions.answerD: Stay directly in front of another vehicle to be seen in their headlights when riding at night.
questions.explanation: Strategies for safely riding at night include reducing your speed, increasing your following distance, using the lights of the car ahead to help see farther down the road, using your high beam headlight (unless following or meeting another vehicle), and being flexible about your lane position.

questions.question: When changing lanes, riders should:
questions.answerA: Rely only on their mirrors to identify other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Turn their head to look for traffic behind them.
questions.answerC: Not worry about other traffic.
questions.answerD: Slam on the brakes to allow any vehicles in their blind spot to pass.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle has blind spots just like any other vehicle. A rider must always turn their head to check for traffic before changing lanes.

questions.question: A group of riders should pass another vehicle:
questions.answerA: In a staggered formation.
questions.answerB: In a pyramid formation.
questions.answerC: One at a time.
questions.answerD: In a splintered formation.
questions.explanation: On a two-lane highway, a group of riders should pass another vehicle one at a time. The second rider should not begin to pass until the first rider has safely re-entered the original lane. Riders should continue in this pattern until they have all safely passed the vehicle.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, which portion of the lane should you ride in?
questions.answerA: The left portion
questions.answerB: The center portion
questions.answerC: The right portion
questions.answerD: The shoulder
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, you should ride in the left portion of the lane to increase your line of sight and make yourself more visible to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerB: Happen at night.
questions.answerC: Are caused by worn tires.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have operated the involved motorcycle for less than six months.
questions.explanation: More than half of all motorcycle crashes involve riders with less than six months of experience on the motorcycle being used.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Signal, use your mirrors, and turn your head.
questions.answerB: Signal and use your mirrors.
questions.answerC: Turn your head and change lanes.
questions.answerD: Signal and change lanes.
questions.explanation: Always use the proper turn signal before a turn or lane change. Use your mirrors and perform head checks before changing lanes to check for traffic surrounding your vehicle.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Always pick one part of the lane to occupy and never leave that part of the lane.
questions.answerB: Vary your lane position as conditions warrant.
questions.answerC: Only ride in the center of the lane so other vehicles can see you more easily.
questions.answerD: Ride in a zigzag pattern so other drivers notice you.
questions.explanation: There is no one lane position that is always best, nor one that should always be avoided. Change your lane position as necessary based on changing road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should travel:
questions.answerA: More slowly than you would during the day under similar conditions.
questions.answerB: At the speed you would travel during the day under similar conditions.
questions.answerC: Faster than you would during the day under similar conditions.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder of the road so other vehicles can see you.
questions.explanation: When riding at night, travel at a slower speed than you would during the day under similar weather and traffic conditions. It can be difficult to see potential hazards in the dark, so slowing down can increase your chances of avoiding any hazards.

questions.question: When looking for a protective jacket or pair of pants, you should look for:
questions.answerA: Items made of leather.
questions.answerB: Items made of polyester.
questions.answerC: Items made of light materials.
questions.answerD: Items that are darkly-colored.
questions.explanation: It is safest to wear long pants and a jacket to fully cover your arms and legs while riding. Clothing made of leather can provide the highest level of protection.

questions.question: The best way to stop quickly is to:
questions.answerA: Use the front brake only.
questions.answerB: Use the front brake first.
questions.answerC: Throttle down and use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: If you need to stop quickly, apply both the front and rear brakes at the same time.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Help you avoid road hazards.
questions.answerB: Help you avoid other drivers’ blind spots.
questions.answerC: Help you avoid being seen by other drivers.
questions.answerD: Increase your ability to be seen by others.
questions.explanation: A well-chosen lane position should increase your ability to see and be seen and keep you out of other drivers' blind spots. It should help you avoid surface hazards, protect your lane from other drivers, communicate your intentions to others, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and offer you an escape route from any hazards that may arise.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a way to prevent a friend from driving while intoxicated?
questions.answerA: Arrange a safe ride home for them.
questions.answerB: Get them involved in activities to slow their drinking and keep them busy while they sober up.
questions.answerC: Make them wait 15 minutes after their last drink before driving.
questions.answerD: Get other friends involved in stopping your friend from driving.
questions.explanation: To prevent someone from drinking and driving, it is a good idea to arrange an alternative way for them to get home, involve them in other activities to slow the pace of their drinking, use any available excuse to keep them from leaving, and recruit friends to help apply peer pressure.

questions.question: The front brake can provide how much of a motorcycle's braking power?
questions.answerA: 10 percent
questions.answerB: 25 percent
questions.answerC: 50 percent
questions.answerD: 75 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. It can provide at least three-quarters of the motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: Your lane position should help you:
questions.answerA: Communicate your intentions to other drivers.
questions.answerB: Keep others from passing you.
questions.answerC: Travel to your destination as quickly as possible.
questions.answerD: Linger in the blind spots of other drivers.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should protect your lane from other drivers while communicating your intentions to them.

questions.question: It is best to not ride directly alongside another vehicle because:
questions.answerA: You may be riding in its blind spot.
questions.answerB: It is distracting to have a vehicle next to you.
questions.answerC: Other drivers may want to use the lane.
questions.answerD: It would be difficult to see what is happening behind you.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous to ride directly alongside a vehicle in another lane because you may be in the vehicle's blind spot and the driver will have no way of knowing you are there. It can also be dangerous because the vehicle may block your path of escape if another hazard arises.

questions.question: When riding, the best protection for an operator is:
questions.answerA: A cushion of space between their vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerB: A good leather jacket.
questions.answerC: Sturdy boots.
questions.answerD: A good understanding of motorcycle laws.
questions.explanation: Your first and best protection against collisions with other vehicles is simply to keep your distance from them. The only way to be sure you will have enough time to react to mistakes made by other drivers is to leave plenty of space between you and the vehicles around you. Wearing proper gear is also important when riding a motorcycle.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle and trying to turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the grip in the direction you want to turn.
questions.answerB: Press the grip opposite of the direction you want to turn.
questions.answerC: Not hold the grip because it can be dangerous.
questions.answerD: Not lean the motorcycle as that can be unsafe.
questions.explanation: When traveling faster than a walking pace, your motorcycle will need to lean to turn. Pressing the grip in the direction you want to turn will cause you to lean in the appropriate direction

questions.question: To increase your visibility, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn off your headlight during the day.
questions.answerB: Wear dark clothes.
questions.answerC: Keep your headlight on at all times.
questions.answerD: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Strategies for making yourself more visible include wearing brightly-colored and reflective clothing, keeping your headlight on at all times, and varying your lane position as conditions demand.

questions.question: Riding with a passenger:
questions.answerA: Usually results in no difference in handling a motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Is usually safe for beginning riders.
questions.answerC: Can affect the handling of a motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Is encouraged to get operators used to different riding situations.
questions.explanation: A passenger puts extra weight on a motorcycle, which causes the motorcycle to handle differently. Only experienced riders should carry passengers.

questions.question: You should check your tires for all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Air pressure.
questions.answerB: Tread.
questions.answerC: General wear.
questions.answerD: Flexibility.
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-ride inspection of your motorcycle, you should check the air pressure, general wear, and tread of your tires.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should be done:
questions.answerA: Before every ride.
questions.answerB: Once a week.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a season.
questions.explanation: To prevent any dangerous situations caused by technical issues, you should perform a thorough inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. Compared to a car, small technical problems can have more serious consequences on a motorcycle.

questions.question: A motorcyclist should continually scan the road ahead for:
questions.answerA: Road conditions.
questions.answerB: Traffic conditions.
questions.answerC: Escape routes.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Scan the road ahead to remain alert to changing traffic conditions, hazardous road conditions, and escape routes. Be prepared to react to any changing conditions.

questions.question: When it starts raining, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Pull off to the side of the road until the rain stops.
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: Avoid riding down the center of a lane under wet conditions. Instead, ride in the tire tracks left by the cars ahead of you. The left tire track will often be best, but this can vary depending on traffic and other conditions.

questions.question: Smoothly downshifting on motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Is a useless action.
questions.answerB: Can allow the rider to engine brake.
questions.answerC: Is illegal.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if other vehicles are around.
questions.explanation: Engine braking by smoothly downshifting can be a useful option for motorcyclists. If you choose to engine brake, apply your brake lights separately to let other drivers know that you are slowing down.

questions.question: If you are preparing to pass another operator on the left, you should:
questions.answerA: Get into the right part of the lane so you can be seen in their side mirror.
questions.answerB: Get into the left part of the lane to increase your line of sight.
questions.answerC: Stay in the center part of the lane so you can be seen in their rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: Weave in your lane to draw attention to yourself.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, ride in the left portion of your lane to increase your line of sight and to make yourself more visible to any drivers in the passing lane. Use your mirrors and turn your head to check for traffic before changing lanes.

questions.question: A flat front tire is especially hazardous because:
questions.answerA: It affects how you steer.
questions.answerB: The front tire provides the power for the bike, so you will lose acceleration.
questions.answerC: The flat tire will shake the bike, making it hard to use the mirrors.
questions.answerD: You won’t be able to use the brake.
questions.explanation: A flat front tire is especially dangerous because it affects your ability to steer. If your front tire goes flat while you are riding, safely exit the road as quickly as possible.

questions.question: Without a helmet, a motorcycle rider is ________ more likely to suffer a critical head injury in a crash.
questions.answerA: Three times
questions.answerB: Four times
questions.answerC: Five times
questions.answerD: Six times
questions.explanation: Without a helmet, a rider is five times more likely to sustain a critical head injury in a crash.

questions.question: Riding alongside another rider:
questions.answerA: Allows you to maximize the surface of the road.
questions.answerB: Should be avoided because it limits your escape routes.
questions.answerC: Allows you to communicate with one another.
questions.answerD: Makes it easier for other motorists to pass.
questions.explanation: You should not ride alongside another motorcyclist because doing so will limit both of your possible routes of escape if you encounter a hazard.

questions.question: If attempting to brake in a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake more gradually than you would on a straightaway.
questions.answerB: Brake as hard as you would on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: Wait until you are not in the curve to brake.
questions.answerD: Only use the rear brake.
questions.explanation: Because tires have less traction when a motorcycle is leaning than when it is upright, always try to position your motorcycle in an upright position before braking. If you must brake while in a curve, apply the brakes more smoothly and gradually than if your motorcycle was traveling on a straightaway.

questions.question: As the motorcycle’s weight moves forward while braking, you:
questions.answerA: Can apply the front brake harder.
questions.answerB: Should lessen the amount of pressure on the front brake.
questions.answerC: Can apply the rear brake harder.
questions.answerD: Lose traction.
questions.explanation: As your weight shifts forward while you are braking, the amount of traction available to the front wheel increases. This means that you can begin to apply the front brake harder.

questions.question: To stop quickly, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Use the rear brake firmly while gradually increasing the braking pressure of the front brake.
questions.explanation: To stop quickly, apply both brakes at the same time.

questions.question: When may you not need to increase your following distance?
questions.answerA: When the road is slippery
questions.answerB: When there is a lot of traffic
questions.answerC: When you can see through the vehicle in front of you
questions.answerD: When it is raining
questions.explanation: An increased following distance is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a longer following distance.

questions.question: Generally, the body eliminates how many alcoholic drinks per hour?
questions.answerA: One
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: Three
questions.answerD: Four
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. The amount of time required to lower a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) can vary, so it is safest not to operate any motor vehicle after consuming any amount of alcohol.

questions.question: The center portion of a lane:
questions.answerA: Is always the best part of the lane for a motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Often contains oil and grease, but is usually safe for riding.
questions.answerC: Often contains oil and grease, and is never safe for riding.
questions.answerD: Is the smoothest part of the lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars collect in a strip in the center of each lane. Unless the road is wet, this area still generally offers enough traction for motorcyclists to safely ride. You should still avoid riding on big buildups of oil and grease, often found at busy intersections or near toll booths.

questions.question: Most crashes occur during the day. To lessen the chance of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Wear darkly-colored clothing.
questions.answerB: Wear brightly-colored clothing.
questions.answerC: Not ride during the day.
questions.answerD: Look for safer routes.
questions.explanation: To minimize your chances of being in a crash, you should make yourself as visible as possible by wearing brightly-colored clothing when riding, even during the day.

questions.question: When riding downhill on a motorcycle with a sidecar:
questions.answerA: Stopping will be easier than when riding without a sidecar.
questions.answerB: Stopping will take longer than when riding without a sidecar.
questions.answerC: You cannot stop.
questions.answerD: Stopping is about as easy as it is when riding without the sidecar.
questions.explanation: Riding with a sidecar increases the weight of a motorcycle and increases the braking force needed to stop the motorcycle. Slowing and stopping take longer when riding a vehicle downhill than when riding on a flat surface.

questions.question: When braking on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerB: Use abrupt pressure on the front brake to prevent locking the front tire.
questions.answerC: Only use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Use either brake, but use only one brake.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should use both brakes to slow down. Squeeze the brake lever gradually to avoid locking the front wheel and use gentle pressure on the rear brake.

questions.question: As you slow or stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift up through the gears.
questions.answerB: Shift down through the gears.
questions.answerC: Take the bike out of gear.
questions.answerD: Stay in the same gear.
questions.explanation: You should shift down through the gears with the clutch as you slow or stop. Stay in first gear while you are stopped so you can move quickly, if needed.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerA: Slow or stop
questions.answerB: Left turn
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing downward, it means the operator plans to slow down or stop.

questions.question: If you are riding behind a car, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in a lane position that makes you visible to the driver.
questions.answerB: Always ride in the far left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned about your placement.
questions.answerD: Always ride in the far right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When riding directly behind a car, it is usually safest to ride in the center portion of your lane. If you are riding in the center of the lane, you are most likely to be visible in the rearview mirror of the vehicle ahead. Most drivers check their rearview mirror more frequently than they check their side mirrors.

questions.question: The Motorcycle Safety Foundation recommends a SEE strategy to make safe judgments while riding. What does "SEE" stand for?
questions.answerA: Search, Evaluate, Execute
questions.answerB: Scan, Error, Elevate
questions.answerC: Stop, Extend, Enter
questions.answerD: Share, Extra, Escalate
questions.explanation: Experienced riders use a SEE strategy while riding to make safe judgements. "SEE" stands for Search, Evaluate, and Execute.

questions.question: A face shield:
questions.answerA: Provides protection for the eyes and face.
questions.answerB: Is not recommended.
questions.answerC: Is required.
questions.answerD: Does not protect the face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, impact-resistant face shield provides the greatest degree of protection for a wearer's eyes and face. Eyeglasses or sunglasses are not an adequate substitute. In Vermont, you are not legally required to wear eye or face protection if your motorcycle has a windshield, though it is recommended.

questions.question: To effectively provide protection for a motorcycle rider, pants should:
questions.answerA: Be made of a soft material.
questions.answerB: Be made of a heavy material.
questions.answerC: Fit loosely enough that they flap in the wind.
questions.answerD: Be short and expose some parts of the legs.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should wear pants that cover your entire legs and are made of leather or another sturdy synthetic material. Clothing should fit snugly enough that it does not flap in the wind but not so snugly that it restricts your movement.

questions.question: To receive maximum protection, wear a helmet that is certified by the:
questions.answerA: U.S. Department of Transportation.
questions.answerB: Federal Trade Commission.
questions.answerC: Federal Transportation Network.
questions.answerD: National Association of Helmets.
questions.explanation: To get maximum protection, use a motorcycle helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) standards.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should:
questions.answerA: Do one, then the other.
questions.answerB: Do both at the same time.
questions.answerC: Always apply the brakes first, then swerve.
questions.answerD: Try instead to use only the brakes.
questions.explanation: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should perform both actions separately. Brake then swerve, or swerve then brake. Do not do both at the same time.

questions.question: In the context of group riding, what does the hand signal pictured mean?
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Danger ahead.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.answerD: Merge.
questions.explanation: Hand signals are an important part of communication when riding in groups. If a lead rider extends their left arm straight down with their palm facing back, the group of riders should come to a stop.

questions.question: If you must stop quickly in a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Straighten up, square the handlebars, and stop.
questions.answerB: Abruptly apply both brakes while leaning.
questions.answerC: Apply only the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Apply only the front brake.
questions.explanation: If you must stop quickly while in a curve, you should first straighten and square the handlebars, then stop. If straightening your motorcycle is not possible, you should apply the brakes smoothly and gradually, reduce your lean angle, then increase the brake pressure as you slow down.

questions.question: When choosing a lane position, you should consider:
questions.answerA: Whether or not other drivers will see you.
questions.answerB: How many cars are on the road ahead.
questions.answerC: Which portion of the lane will result in a shorter trip.
questions.answerD: If you can pass more vehicles in a certain position than in another.
questions.explanation: While a properly chosen lane position can offer several advantages, you should be certain that your lane position will allow you to be seen by others and have an adequate space cushion.

questions.question: Taking a turn too fast:
questions.answerA: Is acceptable as long as you stay under the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Is safer on a motorcycle than in a car.
questions.answerC: Is acceptable as long as no vehicles are near you.
questions.answerD: Can cause you to end up in another lane or leave the road.
questions.explanation: Taking a turn too fast is dangerous. If you cannot hold the turn, you may end up turning into another lane or even off of the road entirely. Use caution when taking a turn.

questions.question: You should do all of the following to lesson your chances of being in a crash, except:
questions.answerA: Be visible by wearing proper clothing and using your headlight.
questions.answerB: Communicate your intentions by using your turn signals and brake light.
questions.answerC: Search for hazards in your path.
questions.answerD: Hope the other drivers see you.
questions.explanation: To minimize your risk of a crash, ensure that you are visible to other drivers, communicating your intentions to other drivers, and maintaining a cushion of space around you. You should search for, identify, and separate hazards. Be prepared to react to anything that happens.

questions.question: Impairment from drinking alcohol occurs:
questions.answerA: Well below the legal limit.
questions.answerB: Once reaching the legal limit.
questions.answerC: Just above the legal limit.
questions.answerD: Well above the legal limit.
questions.explanation: It is never safe to operate a motorcycle after consuming any amount of alcohol. Impairment of the skills needed to safely ride begins well below the legal limit.

questions.question: If you wait one hour to ride after having one alcoholic drink:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and driving.
questions.answerB: Your riding skills will not be affected by the alcohol.
questions.answerC: Effects from the alcohol may still remain.
questions.answerD: You will be fine as long as you ride slowly.
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. However, it is still possible for alcohol to accumulate in a person's system even if they consume only one drink per hour. This accumulation can still affect their ability to ride safely.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Always avoid the left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: Always avoid the right portion of a lane.
questions.answerC: Always avoid the center portion of a lane.
questions.answerD: Use whichever portion of the lane is safest.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that you always need to avoid. Adjust your position in response to changing conditions on the road.

questions.question: If another driver is following you too closely, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Not worry about them.
questions.answerB: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.answerD: Get off the roadway.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Increasing your speed may only encourage the driver to tailgate you at a higher speed.

questions.question: Which of the following is a poor reason to sound your horn?
questions.answerA: A driver in the lane next to you is too close to the vehicle ahead of them.
questions.answerB: A parked car has a person in the driver’s seat.
questions.answerC: You want people to look at your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: You are passing someone who is in the street.
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to sound your horn before riding past a vehicle or pedestrian that may move into your lane. If you see a driver in an adjacent lane driving too closely to the vehicle ahead of them, you may assume that they want to pass and may cut in front of you to do so. If you see a person in the driver's seat of a parked car, or if you see a pedestrian or bicyclist in the street, it is a good idea to sound your horn as you pass.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signals to indicate that you plan to change lanes.
questions.answerB: Tailgate other drivers.
questions.answerC: Keep your eyes focused no more than 15 feet in front of your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Not use a headlight during the day.
questions.explanation: To lessen the chances of a crash occurring, you should make yourself visible, communicate your intentions to others, maintain adequate space cushions, search your path of travel at least 12 seconds ahead, identify and separate hazards, and be prepared to react to changing conditions.

questions.question: Where should a load be placed?
questions.answerA: As low as possible
questions.answerB: As high as possible
questions.answerC: Behind the rear axle
questions.answerD: On one side of the motorcycle
questions.explanation: Loads should kept low, either fastened securely or in saddlebags. Piling loads against a sissy bar or frame on the back of a seat is dangerous because it can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and change the balance of the motorcycle. Loads should be equally distributed on both sides of the motorcycle.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to blend into traffic and not be noticed by other drivers.
questions.answerB: Not use turn signals unless you are traveling at night.
questions.answerC: Use your turn signals when changing lanes and making turns.
questions.answerD: Ride closely to the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, ensure that you are visible to others on the road. Communicate your intentions through your turn signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain an adequate space cushion, scan your path of travel 12 seconds ahead of your vehicle, and be prepared to act if any hazards arise.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked cars to your right when there is no oncoming traffic to your left, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay toward the right side of your lane.
questions.answerB: Stay toward the left side of your lane.
questions.answerC: Look to your left frequently.
questions.answerD: Use your rearview mirrors more frequently than usual.
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked cars, it is generally best to stay on the side of your lane that is not directly next to the cars. This will help to protect you from potential hazards like car doors being opened or people stepping out from between the cars. If there is traffic coming from the opposite direction, it is a good idea to stay in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: Most motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Have only a front brake.
questions.answerB: Have only a rear brake.
questions.answerC: Have brakes in both the front and rear.
questions.answerD: Have three brakes: one in the front, one in the rear, and an emergency brake.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles generally have two brakes, one for the front wheel and one for the rear wheel.

questions.question: Studies show that most crash-involved riders:
questions.answerA: Under-brake the front tire and over-break the rear tire.
questions.answerB: Over-break the front tire and under-brake the rear tire.
questions.answerC: Only use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Only use the rear brake.
questions.explanation: Most riders involved in crashes under-brake the front tire and over-brake the rear.

questions.question: When approaching an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume other drivers see you, especially if they make eye contact.
questions.answerB: Never assume other drivers see you.
questions.answerC: Stay focused on moving through the intersection.
questions.answerD: Speed up to make others notice you.
questions.explanation: Never assume that other drivers see you, even if they make eye contact with you. It is not uncommon for drivers to look directly at a motorcyclist and still fail to notice them. Always reduce your speed when approaching an intersection.

questions.question: Because of their small size, motorcycles seem to be:
questions.answerA: Traveling faster than they actually are.
questions.answerB: Traveling more slowly than they actually are.
questions.answerC: Not moving when they actually are.
questions.answerD: Closer than they actually are.
questions.explanation: Because of their size, motorcycles may seem to be traveling faster than they actually are.

questions.question: Where is the greatest potential for conflict between motorcycle operators and other drivers?
questions.answerA: At intersections
questions.answerB: On highways
questions.answerC: On rural roads
questions.answerD: In parking lots
questions.explanation: Intersections present the greatest potential for conflict between motorcyclists and other drivers. Riders should use extra caution when approaching and riding through intersections.

questions.question: When using a motorcycle with which you are unfamiliar, you should:
questions.answerA: Test the seat to make sure it is comfortable.
questions.answerB: Assume the motorcycle is in good riding condition.
questions.answerC: Work the throttle, clutch, and brakes a few times before riding.
questions.answerD: Ride as you usually do, since most bikes are similar.
questions.explanation: Since all motorcycles are somewhat different, you should be very careful when using one that is new to you. Familiarize yourself with the motorcycle before setting off. Learn the gear pattern before riding by working the throttle, clutch, and brakes a few times.

questions.question: When looking through a turn to see where you are going, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn just your head.
questions.answerB: Turn your head and shoulders.
questions.answerC: Turn just your shoulders.
questions.answerD: Turn your entire body.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn only your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: When you park a motorcycle next to a curb, it should be:
questions.answerA: Parked at a 90-degree angle with the rear wheel touching the curb.
questions.answerB: Parked at a 45-degree angle with the front tire touching the curb.
questions.answerC: Parked like a car, with the front and rear wheels the same distance from the curb.
questions.answerD: Parked at the left edge of the parking space so approaching drivers can more easily see the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: When parking a motorcycle next to a curb, you should create at a 90-degree angle with the curb by touching your rear wheel to the curb.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield protects the wearer from:
questions.answerA: Insects.
questions.answerB: Headlight glare.
questions.answerC: Noise.
questions.answerD: Sunshine.
questions.explanation: In addition to protecting your face from injury in a crash, a face shield protects you from wind, dust, dirt, rain, insects, and pebbles thrown up from surrounding vehicles.

questions.question: Signals on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Are not very important.
questions.answerB: Are even more important than signals on larger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Should not be used unless another vehicle is right next to the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Are less important than signals on larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: Because motorcyclists are more vulnerable than the drivers of cars and trucks, appropriate use of signals by motorcyclists is even more important than it is for other drivers.

questions.question: To get the best possible protection, wear a helmet that:
questions.answerA: Fits snugly.
questions.answerB: Is well-worn and broken in.
questions.answerC: Is pretty loose.
questions.answerD: Does not have a chinstrap.
questions.explanation: Choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. It should fit you snugly all the way around and be free of obvious defects.

questions.question: When entering a curve, a group should:
questions.answerA: Ride in a single-file formation.
questions.answerB: Ride in a staggered formation.
questions.answerC: Ride in pairs.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is usually best, a group should switch into a single-file formation when turning, taking curves, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: To control your motorcycle well, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit with your arms propping you up rather than steering.
questions.answerB: Keep your knees against the gas tank for balance.
questions.answerC: Allow your feet to hang off the footrests.
questions.answerD: Sit so far back that you must stretch to reach the handgrips.
questions.explanation: When riding, keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance in turns. Sit so that you can use your arms to steer rather than to prop yourself up. Sit far enough forward that your arms are slightly bent when you hold the handgrips, and keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: Drivers on an entrance ramp may not see you on the highway. What should you do to help an entering driver merge safely?
questions.answerA: Stay in your lane, as it is not your responsibility to be seen.
questions.answerB: Change to a lane away from the entrance ramp, if possible.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Weave within your lane to be more obvious to the entering driver.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision, always allow merging vehicles plenty of space to safely enter traffic. Change lanes away from the entrance ramp if there is room to do so safely. If there isn't another lane available, adjust your speed to open up space for the merging driver.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of protective riding gear?
questions.answerA: A leather jacket
questions.answerB: Boots that go above the ankle
questions.answerC: Hearing protection
questions.answerD: Pants made of a soft material
questions.explanation: Appropriate protective gear for motorcycling includes a jacket and pants made of leather or another sturdy material; footwear that covers and supports your ankles; and hearing protection, even if you wear a helmet.

questions.question: If you are riding in the right side of your lane while following a car:
questions.answerA: You are likely riding in the best position to be seen.
questions.answerB: You may not be seen unless the driver uses their side mirror.
questions.answerC: The driver will most likely assume you are there.
questions.answerD: You are discouraging other drivers from sharing your lane.
questions.explanation: When riding behind a passenger vehicle, it is usually best to ride in the center of the lane so you will be visible in the driver's rearview mirror. Most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than their side mirrors, so this lane position will increase your chances of being seen.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat while you are riding and you must stop, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Relax on the handle grips.
questions.answerB: Shift your weight toward the good tire.
questions.answerC: Brake on the good tire and steer to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes and stop quickly.
questions.explanation: If one of your tires goes flat, hold both handle grips firmly, ease off of the throttle, and maintain a straight course. If you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is not flat (if you are certain of which tire that is). As you slow down, edge to the side of the road, squeeze the clutch, and stop.

questions.question: When riding behind a car, you should ride:
questions.answerA: In any part of the lane.
questions.answerB: In the part of the lane closest to the shoulder.
questions.answerC: In the part of the lane that places your image in the car's rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: As close to the car as possible.
questions.explanation: When following a car, you should ride in a position that allows the driver to see you in their rearview mirror. Usually, that means riding in the center portion of the lane. Because most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than they check their side mirrors, being in this lane position increases the chance that they will see you.

questions.question: To lean a motorcycle when making a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Always press on the left handgrip.
questions.answerB: Always press on the right handgrip.
questions.answerC: Press on the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press on the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: To turn, a motorcycle must lean. To make the motorcycle lean, press on the handgrip in the direction of the turn.

questions.question: Your lane position should not:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerB: Help you avoid surface hazards.
questions.answerC: Provide you with an escape route.
questions.answerD: Welcome other drivers into your lane.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position can optimize a number of safety factors. Your lane position should keep you out of other vehicles’ blind spots, increase your ability to see and be seen, help you avoid surface hazards, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and provide you with an escape route from any hazards that might arise. You should be positioned in a way that discourages other drivers from trying to share your lane.

questions.question: When braking:
questions.answerA: Use only one brake if it is a non-emergency situation.
questions.answerB: Only use both brakes if you are riding on wet pavement.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes regardless of the circumstances.
questions.answerD: Use only the front brake.
questions.explanation: You should use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, clothing:
questions.answerA: Should be loose enough to flap in the wind.
questions.answerB: Should not cover your arms or legs completely.
questions.answerC: Should not include a jacket if the weather is warm.
questions.answerD: Can provide protection in the event of a crash.
questions.explanation: The right clothing can provide vital protection if you are involved in a collision. Always wear a jacket and pants that fully cover your arms and legs, even in warm weather. Clothing should fit snugly enough that it does not flap in the wind but should also be loose enough that your movement is not restricted.

questions.question: If wearing footwear with laces, the laces:
questions.answerA: Should be tucked in.
questions.answerB: Should hang loose.
questions.answerC: Should be taken off of the footwear.
questions.answerD: Should be glued together.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should securely tuck in the laces of your footwear so that they will not catch on your motorcycle.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat and you must brake, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brake of the tire that is not flat.
questions.answerB: Apply the brake of the tire that is flat.
questions.answerC: Apply both brakes.
questions.answerD: Not use either brake.
questions.explanation: If either of your tires go flat and you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is not flat (if you are certain of which tire that is).

questions.question: When carrying a passenger in a sidecar, you should:
questions.answerA: Begin slowing sooner than usual.
questions.answerB: Begin slowing later than usual.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes more firmly than usual to stop quickly.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes more softly than usual to keep from overworking them.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a passenger in a sidecar will affect the handling of your motorcycle. Expect your motorcycle to require extra space to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and the brakes.
questions.answerC: Pull in the clutch when turning.
questions.answerD: Ride under the speed limit.
questions.explanation: In potential high-risk areas, such as near intersections, shopping areas, school zones, and construction zones, cover the clutch and both brakes to reduce the time you will need to react to potential hazards.

questions.question: When preparing to pass a vehicle on the left, it is important to ride on the left side of your lane because:
questions.answerA: The right side could be slippery.
questions.answerB: It will give you the best chance of spotting hazards in the next lane.
questions.answerC: People don’t usually expect to be passed on their left.
questions.answerD: It will place you in the rearview mirror of the car in front of you.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. This lane position will increase your line of sight and make your more visible to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: ____ can remove alcohol and its effects from your body.
questions.answerA: Time
questions.answerB: Coffee
questions.answerC: Exercise
questions.answerD: Fresh air
questions.explanation: The only method that effectively reduces your BAC is not drinking alcohol for a period of time. Coffee, exercise, fresh air, and cold showers cannot reduce your BAC or change the effects of alcohol. They can help you remain awake, but they cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: Which of the following is not considered protective clothing for a motorcyclist?
questions.answerA: A jacket
questions.answerB: Boots
questions.answerC: Gloves
questions.answerD: A stocking cap
questions.explanation: You should wear appropriate protective clothing when riding. Protective garments include sturdy pants and jackets that entirely cover your arms and legs, boots or heavy shoes that cover and support your ankles, and sturdy gloves.

questions.question: Before changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head to check for vehicles in your blind spot.
questions.answerB: Rely on your mirrors to show you all of your surroundings.
questions.answerC: Point in the direction of the lane change.
questions.answerD: Speed up to get ahead of other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like any other vehicle. You should always turn your head to check for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes. Do not rely on your mirrors alone.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerC: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerD: Use your high beam light, if possible.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. Use your high beam headlight, except when following or meeting another vehicle.

questions.question: What does this signal mean?
questions.answerA: Follow me
questions.answerB: Slow down
questions.answerC: Speed up
questions.answerD: Exit
questions.explanation: Hand signals are an important part of communication when riding in groups. This hand signal means "follow me."

questions.question: Compared to riding during the day, a motorcycle operator who is riding at night should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Ride more slowly.
questions.answerB: Allow more space between their motorcycle and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Use their high beam whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Tailgate other vehicles.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: In New Hampshire, a person who is age 21 or older with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of ______ is considered legally intoxicated.
questions.answerA: 0.02 percent
questions.answerB: 0.04 percent
questions.answerC: 0.06 percent
questions.answerD: 0.08 percent
questions.explanation: A person who is of legal drinking age with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher is considered legally intoxicated. It is both illegal and unsafe to ride a motorcycle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a benefit of riding in a close group?
questions.answerA: It takes up minimal space on the highway.
questions.answerB: The group is easy to see.
questions.answerC: The group is unlikely to be split up.
questions.answerD: The riders will get to their destination more quickly in a close group than a group that is spread out.
questions.explanation: Riding in close ranks is recommended over riding in a group that is spread out because the group will take up less space on the road, be easier for others to see, and be less likely to get separated at traffic lights and during passes.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerB: Only protects your eyes.
questions.answerC: Protects more than just your eyes.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield helps protect your entire face, including your eyes. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: The best way to stop quickly is to:
questions.answerA: Use the front brake only.
questions.answerB: Use the rear brake first.
questions.answerC: Throttle down and use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes simultaneously.
questions.explanation: To stop quickly, apply both brakes at the same time. Apply the brakes firmly and do not panic if the brakes lock.

questions.question: The single most effective thing you can do to improve your chances of surviving an accident is:
questions.answerA: Wear a helmet.
questions.answerB: Read books on motorcycle safety.
questions.answerC: Ask others about how to ride more safely.
questions.answerD: Watch training videos.
questions.explanation: The single most important measure you can take to reduce your risk of injury or death in the event of an accident is to wear a helmet.

questions.question: When approaching railroad tracks that cross your lane at an angle, it is usually:
questions.answerA: Safest to ride straight within your lane to cross the tracks.
questions.answerB: Dangerous to ride straight within your lane to cross the tracks.
questions.answerC: Not safe to cross tracks on a motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Safest to cross the tracks by riding on the shoulder of the road.
questions.explanation: When approaching railroad tracks that cross your lane at an angle, it is best to simply cross the tracks while riding straight within your lane. Turning to cross the tracks at a 90-degree angle could be dangerous because you could end up crossing into another lane of traffic.

questions.question: When riding in a group, the best way to keep ranks close while maintaining an adequate safety cushion is to ride:
questions.answerA: In pairs.
questions.answerB: In a staggered formation.
questions.answerC: In a single-file line.
questions.answerD: In a passing formation.
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is the best way to keep ranks close while still maintaining an adequate space cushion for all riders. Ride in a single-file line when riding in curves, turning, or entering or leaving a highway. Never ride side-by-side with another rider.

questions.question: If braking in a curve:
questions.answerA: Only use the front brake.
questions.answerB: It will be the same as braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: You will have more traction as you lean into the curve.
questions.answerD: You may have less traction as you lean into the curve.
questions.explanation: It is possible to use both brakes while turning, but it must be done with great care. Some of the tires' usual traction is being used to make the turn while the motorcycle is leaning, so less traction is available for stopping.

questions.question: When should the front brake be used?
questions.answerA: Any time the rider is slowing or stopping
questions.answerB: Only when slowing or stopping on slippery roads
questions.answerC: Only when slowing or stopping in an emergency
questions.answerD: Only when slowing or stopping in traffic
questions.explanation: A rider should always use both brakes every time they slow or stop.

questions.question: Each traffic lane gives the motorcyclist how many paths of travel?
questions.answerA: One
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: Three
questions.answerD: Four
questions.explanation: Each traffic lane provides three paths of travel for motorcyclists: the left, center, and right portions of the lane.

questions.question: Which of the following surfaces provides the best traction for a motorcycle?
questions.answerA: A gravel road
questions.answerB: Dry pavement
questions.answerC: Mud
questions.answerD: Lane markings
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: For the best protection, jackets and pants:
questions.answerA: Should cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.answerB: Should be loose and flap in the wind while you are riding.
questions.answerC: Should only partially cover your arms and legs.
questions.answerD: Should be made of wool.
questions.explanation: To provide adequate protection when riding, jackets and pants should cover your arms and legs completely. Your clothing should fit snugly but be loose enough to let you move freely. Leather or newer kinds of synthetic materials provide the best protection in the case of an accident.

questions.question: Moving into another lane while taking a curve is often the result of:
questions.answerA: Taking the turn too fast.
questions.answerB: Lanes that are too narrow.
questions.answerC: Not knowing how to steer.
questions.answerD: Lanes that are too wide.
questions.explanation: Trying to enter a curve or turn at a speed that is too fast for conditions may cause you to cross into another lane of traffic or leave the road entirely.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerB: Are caused by worn tires.
questions.answerC: Happen in the dark.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have little experience on their motorcycles.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes involve riders with little experience on their motorcycle.

questions.question: Under normal circumstances, maintain a following distance of at least:
questions.answerA: One second.
questions.answerB: Two seconds.
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should maintain a minimum two-second following distance. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: If a friend has been drinking and wants to ride their motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Let them.
questions.answerB: Encourage them to take less-crowded roads.
questions.answerC: Push their bike over.
questions.answerD: Encourage friends to talk them out of riding.
questions.explanation: Never let someone ride if they have had too much to drink. Do whatever you can to prevent them from riding. It can be helpful to recruit a group of friends to intervene and apply peer pressure to the person.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a piece of protective clothing for a motorcycle rider?
questions.answerA: Jacket
questions.answerB: Boots
questions.answerC: Gloves
questions.answerD: Sandals
questions.explanation: When riding, it is safest for a motorcyclist to wear a helmet, eye protection, a jacket, long pants, sturdy boots, and gloves.

questions.question: To get the best protection, be sure that your helmet:
questions.answerA: Meets Department of Transportation guidelines.
questions.answerB: Looks sturdy.
questions.answerC: Is inexpensive.
questions.answerD: Is in your favorite color.
questions.explanation: Choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. It should fit you snugly all the way around and be free of obvious defects.

questions.question: On a motorcycle, a horn:
questions.answerA: Is useless.
questions.answerB: Usually cannot be heard by others.
questions.answerC: Can be used to get someone’s attention quickly.
questions.answerD: Should not be used.
questions.explanation: Your horn can be a useful tool if you need to get someone's attention quickly. However, because a motorcycle's horn is not as loud as a car's, other drivers may not notice that you are sounding your horn. You should never rely only on your horn to deal with a hazard.

questions.question: A proper lane position can help you do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Avoid other drivers' blindspots.
questions.answerB: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerC: Go faster.
questions.answerD: Set up for turns.
questions.explanation: Your lane position affects a number of factors that are important to your safety on the road. Among other things, your position should help you increase your ability to see and be seen, avoid other drivers' blind spots, and set you up for any turns you plan to make.

questions.question: When riding at night you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerC: Use the vehicle in front of you to help see.
questions.answerD: Wear tinted glasses.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a safe step in preventing fatigue while riding?
questions.answerA: Protecting yourself from the elements
questions.answerB: Taking artificial stimulants
questions.answerC: Limiting the distance ridden in one day
questions.answerD: Taking frequent breaks
questions.explanation: When taking a long trip, be sure to schedule in frequent breaks to rest and try not to ride more than six hours in one day. Wind, cold, and rain can make you tire quickly, so be sure to dress to protect yourself from the elements. Avoid taking artificial stimulants, as the effects when they wear off can be very dangerous.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerB: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerC: Ride faster than you usually would.
questions.answerD: Avoid using your high beam headlight.
questions.explanation: Because distances are more difficult to judge in the dark than in daylight, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance when riding at night. Use your high beam any time you are not meeting or following another vehicle.

questions.question: When you are being passed from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in any portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When you are being passed from behind, stay in the center portion of your lane. This will discourage the other driver from re-entering your lane before it is safe.

questions.question: Your primary source for information about your motorcycle should be:
questions.answerA: The owner’s manual.
questions.answerB: A book about motorcycles.
questions.answerC: A former owner.
questions.answerD: Someone knowledgeable about motorcycles.
questions.explanation: Your owner's manual should be your primary source for information about your specific motorcycle. Your manual will include information about the motorcycle's specifications, operation, and suggested maintenance.

questions.question: When being passed from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to move onto the shoulder.
questions.answerB: Use the left portion of your lane.
questions.answerC: Use the center portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Use the right portion of your lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed, the center portion of the lane is generally the safest lane position for a motorcyclist. Riding on the side nearest the passing vehicle increases the risk of colliding with it. Riding on the side farthest from the passing vehicle can also be dangerous because it may prompt the driver to return to your lane before it is safe to do so.

questions.question: When braking, you should use:
questions.answerA: Only the front brake.
questions.answerB: Only the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Both brakes.
questions.answerD: Either brake, but never both at the same time.
questions.explanation: Always simultaneously use both brakes to stop. The brakes are most effective when used at the same time.

questions.question: To swerve, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn the handlebars quickly.
questions.answerB: Shift your weight quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the opposite direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: To swerve, apply a small amount of pressure to the handgrip located on the side of your intended direction of escape. To swerve to the left, press the left handgrip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handgrip, then the left.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerB: Only protects your eyes.
questions.answerC: Helps protect your whole face.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as effectively as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield protects your entire face in a crash. Goggles protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for a face shield or goggles.

questions.question: When being passed, do not move into the portion of the lane farthest from the passing vehicle because:
questions.answerA: The passing vehicle may re-enter your lane too early.
questions.answerB: You may prevent another vehicle from passing you.
questions.answerC: The portion of the lane nearest the passing vehicle is better.
questions.answerD: You are more likely to experience a wind blast from the passing vehicle on the far side of the lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed, you should not ride on the side of your lane that is farthest from the passing vehicle. Doing so may tempt the driver to return to your lane before there is actually room for them to do so safely.

questions.question: How often should a motorcycle operator check their mirrors?
questions.answerA: Never
questions.answerB: Occasionally
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: More often than the amount time spent looking ahead
questions.explanation: It is recommended that you frequently check your mirrors to be aware of potential hazards behind you.

questions.question: Maximum straight-line braking is done by:
questions.answerA: Using the front brake, then the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Using the rear brake, then the front brake.
questions.answerC: Using the front and rear brakes at the same time without locking either wheel.
questions.answerD: Using the front and rear brakes at the same time while locking the rear wheel.
questions.explanation: Maximum straight-line braking is accomplished by simultaneously applying both the front and rear brakes without locking either wheel.

questions.question: To accommodate a passenger, you may have to:
questions.answerA: Adjust the shocks.
questions.answerB: Adjust the handlebars.
questions.answerC: Adjust the brakes.
questions.answerD: Adjust the throttle.
questions.explanation: Because of the extra weight placed on a motorcycle by a passenger, you may need to adjust the motorcycle's shocks before carrying a passenger. Because the motorcycle will sit at a different angle, you should also adjust the headlight and mirrors to compensate for the additional weight.

questions.question: The front brake supplies how much of a motorcycle's stopping power?
questions.answerA: About one-quarter
questions.answerB: About one-half
questions.answerC: About three-quarters
questions.answerD: All the stopping power
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. It can provide three-fourths of the bike's total stopping power.

questions.question: Studies show that when motorcycles have their headlights turned on during the day:
questions.answerA: They are not as easy to see as other vehicles.
questions.answerB: They are more visible to other drivers than when their headlights are turned off.
questions.answerC: Other drivers are often confused.
questions.answerD: They are less safe than when their headlights are turned off.
questions.explanation: The best way to help other drivers see your motorcycle is to keep your headlight on whenever you ride. During the day, a motorcycle with its headlight on is twice as likely to be noticed.

questions.question: To be effective, an eye or face shield should be all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Free of scratches.
questions.answerB: Resistant to penetration.
questions.answerC: Able to fasten securely.
questions.answerD: Airtight.
questions.explanation: To be effective, eye protection and face shields must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; give a clear view to either side; fasten securely; permit air to pass through; and permit enough room for eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn underneath.

questions.question: How can you discourage another vehicle from sharing your lane?
questions.answerA: Ride in the middle of your lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of your lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Swerve from side to side in your lane.
questions.explanation: To discourage automobile drivers from trying to share your lane, ride in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: Riding gloves are often:
questions.answerA: Made of leather.
questions.answerB: Made of wool.
questions.answerC: Not pre-curved.
questions.answerD: Unsafe for the rider.
questions.explanation: Gloves designed for motorcycle riding are usually made of leather. In addition to improving your grip, gloves provide protection for a rider's hands and fingers.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: Always look through a turn to where you want to go. Turn only your head to look, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: Where is the throttle usually located?
questions.answerA: Near the left footrest
questions.answerB: Near the right footrest
