questions.answerB: Begin slowing later than usual.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes more firmly than usual to stop quickly.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes more softly than usual to keep from overworking them.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a passenger in a sidecar will affect the handling of your motorcycle. Expect your motorcycle to require extra space to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: The control for the rear brake is usually located:
questions.answerA: On the right handlebar.
questions.answerB: On the left handlebar.
questions.answerC: Near the left foot.
questions.answerD: Near the right foot.
questions.explanation: The rear brake of a motorcycle is usually operated with the right foot.

questions.question: To be effective, a face shield should not:
questions.answerA: Be free of scratches.
questions.answerB: Allow clear views to both sides.
questions.answerC: Be airtight.
questions.answerD: Fasten securely.
questions.explanation: An effective face shield should be free of scratches, be resistant to penetration, allow clear views to both sides, fasten securely, permit air to pass through, and provide enough space for eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn underneath. It is important for a face shield to permit the passage of air because an airtight face shield can create fogging and make it difficult for a rider to see.

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are designed to:
questions.answerA: Prevent skidding and wheel lock-up.
questions.answerB: Prevent brakes from activating if the roadway is dry.
questions.answerC: Apply brakes automatically.
questions.answerD: Warn you when your brake pad needs replacing.
questions.explanation: Some motorcycles are equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS). ABS is designed to prevent skidding and wheel lock-up when motorcyclists are stopping in straight-line, panic situations. ABS operates when maximum pressure is applied to both the front and rear brake controls. If electronic sensors detect the possibility of a wheel lock, brake hydraulic pressure is released then re-applied to maintain maximum braking effectiveness.

questions.question: A wobble, or shaking of the front wheel and handlebars, may be caused by:
questions.answerA: Incorrect tire pressure.
questions.answerB: Brakes that are not working properly.
questions.answerC: A balanced load.
questions.answerD: Excessive wind.
questions.explanation: Most wobbles are caused by improper loading of the motorcycle, unsuitable accessories, or incorrect tire pressure.

questions.question: When adjusting your mirrors, you should focus on:
questions.answerA: The road behind and to the side of your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Your arms.
questions.answerC: The road in front of your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: The side of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Adjust your mirrors so you can see the lane behind you and as much as possible of the lane next to you. When properly adjusted, a mirror may show the edge of your arm or shoulder, but it’s the road behind you and to the side of you that is most important.

questions.question: If you must ride over an obstacle, you should:
questions.answerA: Decrease your speed as much as possible.
questions.answerB: Lean the motorcycle to one side.
questions.answerC: Speed up, if possible.
questions.answerD: Stay on your seat and remove your feet from the footrests.
questions.explanation: If you are unable avoid an obstacle and must instead ride over it, slow down and approach the obstacle at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Keep your motorcycle straight up and down, if possible. Just before contact, roll off the throttle slightly to lighten the front end of the motorcycle.

questions.question: Before changing lanes, motorcycle riders should turn their heads to look over their shoulders because:
questions.answerA: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like other vehicles.
questions.answerB: They can catch the attention of other drivers by turning their heads.
questions.answerC: Mirrors are not really helpful.
questions.answerD: They should try to make eye contact with surrounding drivers.
questions.explanation: Like any other vehicle, a motorcycle has blind spots that cannot be seen by a rider using their mirrors. A motorcyclist should always turn their head to check for vehicles or other hazards in their blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: It is most important to flash your brake light when:
questions.answerA: Passing another vehicle.
questions.answerB: You will be slowing down suddenly.
questions.answerC: There is a stop sign ahead.
questions.answerD: Your signals do not work.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle's single brake light is not as noticeable as the two larger brake lights of a car or truck. It can be a good idea to flash your brake light to help others notice it, especially when you need to slow down more quickly than surrounding drivers may expect.

questions.question: Intersections are usually:
questions.answerA: Safe since there is so much traffic there.
questions.answerB: A dangerous spot for riders.
questions.answerC: Difficult to figure out.
questions.answerD: Safer than the open road.
questions.explanation: Intersections can be dangerous because they present the greatest degree of potential conflict between motorcyclists and other drivers.

questions.question: Where is the engine cut-off switch usually located?
questions.answerA: Near the left handgrip
questions.answerB: Near the right handgrip
questions.answerC: Near the left footrest
questions.answerD: Near the right footrest
questions.explanation: The engine cut-off switch is generally located next to the right handgrip. It is important to know where all of your motorcycle's controls are located before starting out.

questions.question: During acceleration, a sidecar attached to a motorcycle will:
questions.answerA: Feel like it is lagging behind.
questions.answerB: Feel like it is accelerating faster than the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Vibrate uncontrollably.
questions.answerD: Make acceleration seem faster.
questions.explanation: A sidecar is essentially an unpowered mass attached to the side of your motorcycle. Due to its inertia, it will feel like it is lagging behind when you accelerate.

questions.question: Passengers should:
questions.answerA: Lean as the operator leans.
questions.answerB: Hold onto their seat.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back on the bike as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto the operator.
questions.explanation: Passengers should sit directly behind the operator and lean as the operator leans. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator, holding onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: When stopping behind a vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop far behind the vehicle, then slowly creep up.
questions.answerB: Stay well behind the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Make a quick stop right behind the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Stay about four car lengths behind the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Stay well behind the vehicle in front of you, even if you are both stopped. The vehicle could back up unexpectedly, or you may need space to get out of the way of another vehicle bearing down on you from behind.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Squeeze the front brake and press the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Grab at the front brake and squeeze the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Jam on the front brake and grab at the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Press down on the front brake and jam on the rear brake.
questions.explanation: To brake, squeeze the front brake lever and press down on the rear brake pedal. Always use both brakes when slowing or stopping.

questions.question: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to make eye contact with other drivers.
questions.answerB: Ride with your headlight on.
questions.answerC: Reduce your space cushion.
questions.answerD: Ride in a weaving pattern.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, leave your headlight turned on and ride in a lane position that most easily allows oncoming traffic to see you. Maintain a space cushion that allows you to take evasive action if necessary. Never assume that another driver sees you, even if you make eye contact with the driver.

questions.question: Signals on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Are not very important.
questions.answerB: Are even more important than signals on larger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Should not be used unless another vehicle is right next to the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Are less important than signals on larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: Because motorcyclists are more vulnerable than the drivers of cars and trucks, appropriate use of signals by motorcyclists is even more important than it is for other drivers.

questions.question: To prevent getting fatigued on a long ride, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Dress warmly.
questions.answerB: Limit the distance traveled in a day.
questions.answerC: Take frequent rest breaks.
questions.answerD: Take artificial stimulants.
questions.explanation: To reduce the danger of fatigue when riding, dress to protect yourself against tiring weather conditions, such as wind and rain. Limit yourself to no more than about six hours of riding per day and stop for a break at least once every two hours. Avoid taking artificial stimulants since you may experience extreme fatigue when they start to wear off.

questions.question: When approaching an uneven surface, such as a bump or pothole, you should rise slightly off of your seat:
questions.answerA: So you can jump off the motorcycle if you need to.
questions.answerB: So your legs can absorb the shock.
questions.answerC: So other drivers can see you better.
questions.answerD: So you can get a better view of the uneven surface.
questions.explanation: When riding over an uneven surface, rising off of your seat will allow your joints to absorb some of the force of impact. This will make it less likely that the impact of the surface will throw you off of the motorcycle.

questions.question: A motorcyclist is well-protected if they are wearing:
questions.answerA: A jacket that allows the arms to be exposed.
questions.answerB: Boots with tall heels.
questions.answerC: Leather gloves.
questions.answerD: Shoes that stop below their ankle.
questions.explanation: For your protection while riding, it is best to wear a jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs completely. Boots or shoes should be tall and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Footwear should have low heels that will not catch on the foot pegs or rough road surfaces. Gloves made of leather or another durable material will help protect your hands in the event of a crash while providing you with an improved grip on the controls.

questions.question: When being followed too closely by another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Move onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Allow the other driver to pass you.
questions.answerD: Exit the roadway.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them ahead of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: If using a sidecar to transport a load, you should:
questions.answerA: Allow the load to move freely.
questions.answerB: Secure the load so its weight does not shift.
questions.answerC: Place the load unsecured in the seat.
questions.answerD: Secure the load near the front of the sidecar.
questions.explanation: Loads carried in a sidecar should be secured so that they do not shift and affect the motorcycle's handling. Loads should be distributed toward the rear of the sidecar to reduce tipping of the nose of the sidecar in the event of a sudden left turn.

questions.question: When downshifting, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift through multiple gears at a time.
questions.answerB: Shift through one gear at a time.
questions.answerC: Always shift all the way down to neutral first.
questions.answerD: Accelerate.
questions.explanation: When shifting into a lower gear, shift down one gear at a time and ease out the clutch through the friction zone between each downshift.

questions.question: When riding in traffic, it is important to remember that motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Are too small to have blind spots.
questions.answerB: Have blind spots that are too small to cause any problems.
questions.answerC: Have blind spots that require head checks.
questions.answerD: Have only one blind spot.
questions.explanation: Like any other vehicle, motorcycles have blind spots. Always turn your head to check for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: When may you not need to increase your following distance?
questions.answerA: When the road is slippery
questions.answerB: When there is a lot of traffic
questions.answerC: When you can see through the vehicle in front of you
questions.answerD: When it is raining
questions.explanation: An increased following distance is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a longer following distance.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should:
questions.answerA: Only take a few minutes.
questions.answerB: Take more than an hour.
questions.answerC: Be complicated to perform.
questions.answerD: Not be done before every ride.
questions.explanation: It is important to do a thorough inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. This will usually take you only a few minutes.

questions.question: Where should a load be placed?
questions.answerA: As low as possible
questions.answerB: As high as possible
questions.answerC: Behind the rear axle
questions.answerD: On one side of the motorcycle
questions.explanation: Loads should kept low, either fastened securely or in saddlebags. Piling loads against a sissy bar or frame on the back of a seat is dangerous because it can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and change the balance of the motorcycle. Loads should be equally distributed on both sides of the motorcycle.

questions.question: Most crashes happen:
questions.answerA: Far from home.
questions.answerB: On short trips.
questions.answerC: On long rides.
questions.answerD: Several hours into the ride.
questions.explanation: Most crashes happen on trips that are shorter than five miles, just a few minutes after the rider starts out.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerB: Are caused by worn tires.
questions.answerC: Happen in the dark.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have little experience on their motorcycles.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes involve riders with little experience on their motorcycle.

questions.question: Before riding, check all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Your tires' inflation pressure.
questions.answerB: The amount of tread on your tires.
questions.answerC: The reflective quality of your tires.
questions.answerD: The general condition of the sidewalls on your tires.
questions.explanation: Before every ride, be sure to check your tires' inflation pressure, your tires' treadwear, and the general condition of the sidewalls and tread surface on the tires.

questions.question: On which of the following surfaces does a motorcycle have the best traction?
questions.answerA: Dry pavement
questions.answerB: Gravel
questions.answerC: Snow
questions.answerD: Leaves
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: Use a turn signal:
questions.answerA: When you’re planning to increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Only when there is a lot of traffic.
questions.answerC: Any time you plan on changing lanes.
questions.answerD: Only if it is dark outside.
questions.explanation: You should use a turn signal every time you plan to turn or change lanes, even if you think no one else is around to see it.

questions.question: When someone follows you too closely, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Not worry about them and just focus on the road in front of you.
questions.answerC: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder and let them pass.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to change lanes and let them pass you. Speeding up may cause them to tailgate you at a higher speed, only increasing the danger. Never ride on the shoulder of a road because drivers will never expect you to be there and may leave the road suddenly.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Avoid making sudden moves.
questions.answerD: Travel on the shoulder so you are not next to other traffic.
questions.explanation: To ride safely on a slippery surface, you should use both brakes when braking is necessary, reduce your speed, and avoid making sudden moves. Be especially alert to oily areas, shaded areas, dirt, gravel, and bridges, as these surfaces may provide less traction than others.

questions.question: To stop quickly, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Throttle down and use the front brake.
questions.answerB: Use the rear brake only.
questions.answerC: Use the front brake only.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: To stop quickly, apply both brakes at the same time.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should not:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: Avoid sudden moves.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Brake quickly.
questions.explanation: To safely ride on a slippery surface, you should reduce your speed, avoid making sudden movements, and use both brakes if you need to brake.

questions.question: Compared to riding during the day, a motorcycle operator who is riding at night should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Ride more slowly.
questions.answerB: Allow more space between their motorcycle and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Use their high beam whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Tailgate other vehicles.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: During the day, you should:
questions.answerA: Not ride with your headlight on.
questions.answerB: Ride with your headlight on, but only if it is cloudy.
questions.answerC: Always ride with your headlight on.
questions.answerD: Use your headlight if you think it helps.
questions.explanation: You should always have your headlight on when riding, even during the day. This can make you twice as likely to be noticed by other drivers.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerB: Happen at night.
questions.answerC: Are caused by worn tires.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have ridden their motorcycles for less than six months.
questions.explanation: Always take extra care when riding a new or unfamiliar motorcycle. Most crashes involve riders who have had less than six months of experience with the motorcycle that they are using.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerB: Only protects your eyes.
questions.answerC: Helps protect your whole face.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as effectively as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield protects your entire face in a crash. Goggles protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for a face shield or goggles.

questions.question: Why should a load be placed low on a motorcycle?
questions.answerA: If a load is too high, it raises the center of gravity.
questions.answerB: If a load is too high, it may interfere with the turn signals.
questions.answerC: It may be difficult to see over a load that is placed too high.
questions.answerD: Others can't see your load if it is low.
questions.explanation: Placing a load too high on a motorcycle will raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and risk upsetting its balance.

questions.question: What can you do to increase your chances of being seen at an intersection?
questions.answerA: Ride while using your headlight.
questions.answerB: Swerve within your lane to draw attention to your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Raise your arms.
questions.answerD: Avoid using your brakes.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, use your headlight and ride in a lane position that creates the best view of oncoming traffic. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle that allows you to take evasive action.

questions.question: The only way to rid your body of alcohol is through:
questions.answerA: Time.
questions.answerB: Drinking coffee.
questions.answerC: Exercising.
questions.answerD: Taking a cold shower.
questions.explanation: The only way to remove the alcoholic content of a drink from your body is to allow your body time to eliminate it. There are no shortcuts to sobering up.

questions.question: To get the best protection, be sure that your helmet:
questions.answerA: Meets Department of Transportation guidelines.
questions.answerB: Looks sturdy.
questions.answerC: Is inexpensive.
questions.answerD: Is in your favorite color.
questions.explanation: Choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. It should fit you snugly all the way around and be free of obvious defects.

questions.question: If someone is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride faster to shake them.
questions.answerB: Alert the local police.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder of the road.
questions.answerD: Allow them to pass.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to let them get in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let the tailgater pass. Riding faster may only increase the danger by prompting them to continue tailgating you at the higher speed.

questions.question: Shifting to a lower gear produces an effect similar to:
questions.answerA: Accelerating.
questions.answerB: Braking.
questions.answerC: Swerving.
questions.answerD: Turning.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycles have a manual transmission. Downshifting to a lower gear will slow you down.

questions.question: A good way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerB: Ignore them.
questions.answerC: Use your horn and make obscene gestures.
questions.answerD: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to change lanes and let them pass you. Speeding up may cause them to tailgate you at a higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: An advantage to keeping a cushion of space between your motorcycle and other vehicles is that:
questions.answerA: You can pass danger more quickly.
questions.answerB: You will have a more narrow view of the road so you can stay focused.
questions.answerC: You will have more time to react to the movements of others.
questions.answerD: You can more easily follow the path of the next vehicle.
questions.explanation: Maintaining a cushion of space between your motorcycle and other vehicles on the road will give you a clearer view of any emerging hazards, more time to react to hazards, and more space to maneuver around them.

questions.question: A simple way to make your motorcycle easier to see is to:
questions.answerA: Ride with a large flag attached to its frame.
questions.answerB: Ride with the headlight turned on.
questions.answerC: Wave at other drivers.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder whenever possible.
questions.explanation: You can make yourself easier to see by wearing brightly-colored, reflective clothing. Ride with your headlight on at all times and use your turn signals and brake light appropriately.

questions.question: How does the stopping distance for motorcycles compare to the stopping distance for cars?
questions.answerA: Cars need much longer to stop.
questions.answerB: Cars need a little longer to stop.
questions.answerC: Motorcycles need longer to stop.
questions.answerD: Both motorcycles and cars take about the same amount of time to stop.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, the stopping distances for motorcycles is nearly the same as it is for cars. However, slippery pavement makes quick stops especially difficult for motorcycle operators.

questions.question: To be effective, an eye or face shield must:
questions.answerA: Fasten securely.
questions.answerB: Prevent air from passing through.
questions.answerC: Not allow for eyeglasses to fit underneath.
questions.answerD: Restrict your vision to the sides.
questions.explanation: To be effective, an eye or face shield must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; allow clear views to both sides; fasten securely; permit air to pass through to prevent fogging; and allow room for eyeglasses or sunglasses, if needed.

questions.question: To swerve, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn the handlebars quickly.
questions.answerB: Shift your weight quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the opposite direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: To swerve, apply a small amount of pressure to the handgrip located on the side of your intended direction of escape. To swerve to the left, press the left handgrip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handgrip, then the left.

questions.question: When choosing a helmet, you will get the most protection by using a helmet that:
questions.answerA: Fits loosely.
questions.answerB: Meets U.S. DOT standards.
questions.answerC: Has survived a previous crash.
questions.answerD: Provides hearing protection.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you are getting as much protection as possible, choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. Helmets should fit snugly all the way around.

questions.question: Before carrying a passenger in traffic for the first time, you should:
questions.answerA: Read books about carrying passengers.
questions.answerB: Practice riding on an empty road.
questions.answerC: Flash your lights so others can see you.
questions.answerD: Practice riding on the shoulder of a road.
questions.explanation: Before transporting a passenger or heavy load in traffic for the first time, practice riding on a quiet road to get used to how your motorcycle handles differently with the additional weight.

questions.question: Which of the following will help you ride safely on slippery surfaces?
questions.answerA: Using only the front brake
questions.answerB: Using both brakes
questions.answerC: Using the center lane
questions.answerD: Maintaining or increasing your speed
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, reduce your speed, brake using both brakes, and avoid sudden moves. Avoid the center of the lane and instead follow tire tracks left by cars. Always keep an eye out for hazards that may make a road surface especially slippery, such as oil spots and loose gravel.

questions.question: If you are riding behind a car, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in a lane position that makes you visible to the driver.
questions.answerB: Always ride in the far left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned about your placement.
questions.answerD: Always ride in the far right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When riding directly behind a car, it is usually safest to ride in the center portion of your lane. If you are riding in the center of the lane, you are most likely to be visible in the rearview mirror of the vehicle ahead. Most drivers check their rearview mirror more frequently than they check their side mirrors.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Be visible to other drivers.
questions.answerB: Keep your intentions unknown from other drivers.
questions.answerC: Always stay within a foot of another vehicle.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: To receive maximum protection, wear a helmet that is certified by the:
questions.answerA: U.S. Department of Transportation.
questions.answerB: Federal Trade Commission.
questions.answerC: Federal Transportation Network.
questions.answerD: National Association of Helmets.
questions.explanation: To get maximum protection, use a motorcycle helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) standards.

questions.question: Which of the following types of footwear is best for a motorcycle operator?
questions.answerA: Sturdy boots
questions.answerB: Tennis shoes
questions.answerC: Shoes with loose laces
questions.answerD: Sandals
questions.explanation: Sturdy boots or shoes that are high enough to support the ankles can provide the best protection for motorcyclists. Laced up boots are best, but high-top boots or heavy shoes are fine. If a motorcyclist wears shoes that have long laces, they should be sure to securely tuck the laces away before riding.

questions.question: After drinking, what lessens the effects of alcohol?
questions.answerA: Exercise
questions.answerB: Coffee
questions.answerC: Time
questions.answerD: Food
questions.explanation: The liver burns alcohol at a set rate, and there is nothing you can do to speed along the process. The only way to lessen the effects of alcohol is to give your body the time needed to remove it.

questions.question: An advantage to keeping the size of a group of riders small is:
questions.answerA: A small group is less easily separated in traffic than a larger group.
questions.answerB: A small group can disregard traffic laws to stay together.
questions.answerC: Riders will always be trying to catch up to the group.
questions.answerD: It will be difficult to keep track of where everyone is.
questions.explanation: There are several advantages to keeping groups of riders small. In comparison to a large group, a small group is easier for other vehicles to pass safely, is less likely to get separated by traffic or stop lights, and creates less need for slower riders to hurry to catch up to the rest of the group.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use your turn signals when changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Follow other vehicles closely.
questions.answerC: Watch about five feet ahead of your motorcycle while riding.
questions.answerD: Always be ready to use crash-avoidance techniques.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle. Always be ready to avoid an unexpected hazard.

questions.question: Reflective clothing should:
questions.answerA: Be worn at night.
questions.answerB: Not be worn during the day
questions.answerC: Never be worn.
questions.answerD: Not be worn at night.
questions.explanation: Wear reflective materials to increase your visibility, especially when riding at night. Brightly-colored clothing with reflective materials will make you more visible to other road users.

questions.question: If your rear wheel locks while braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Release the brake until the rear tire regains traction, then re-apply the brake.
questions.answerB: Release the brake and only engage the front brake.
questions.answerC: Keep it locked until the motorcycle comes to a stop.
questions.answerD: Release the brake and coast to a stop.
questions.explanation: If your rear wheel locks while braking, do not release the brake. Instead, keep it locked until you come to a full stop.

questions.question: Motorcycle headlights are:
questions.answerA: Usually more powerful than a car’s headlights.
questions.answerB: Usually just as powerful as a car’s headlights.
questions.answerC: Usually not as powerful as a car’s headlights.
questions.answerD: Usually larger than a car’s headlights.
questions.explanation: Motorcycle headlights are generally smaller and less powerful than those of cars.

questions.question: Maintain an adequate following distance behind other vehicles:
questions.answerA: To allow you time and space to identify and react to hazards.
questions.answerB: So you can tailgate.
questions.answerC: To allow for traffic counters to accurately count you as a vehicle.
questions.answerD: To encourage other drivers to cut you off.
questions.explanation: Maintaining an adequate following distance ensures that you will have enough space to stop or swerve out of the way if the vehicle ahead of you stops suddenly. A space cushion also provides you with a better view of any hazards on the road surface, such as potholes.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat while you are riding and you must stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both brakes and stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Shift your weight toward the good tire.
questions.answerC: Brake on the good tire and steer to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Relax on the handgrips.
questions.explanation: If either of your tires go flat while you are riding, hold the handgrips firmly, ease off the throttle, and maintain a straight course. If you need to brake, gradually apply the brake to the tire that is not flat. As you slow down, edge to the side of the road, squeeze the clutch, and stop.

questions.question: If you are unable to avoid hitting an object in the roadway, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up before contact.
questions.answerB: Slow down before contact.
questions.answerC: Lean the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Stay seated on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: If you cannot avoid hitting an obstacle in the roadway, you should try to hit it at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Slow down as much as you can before contact, keep your motorcycle upright, rise slightly off of your seat, and roll the throttle slightly to lighten the front end just before impact.

questions.question: When looking for a protective jacket or pair of pants, you should look for:
questions.answerA: Items made of leather.
questions.answerB: Items made of polyester.
questions.answerC: Items made of light materials.
questions.answerD: Items that are darkly-colored.
questions.explanation: It is safest to wear long pants and a jacket to fully cover your arms and legs while riding. Clothing made of leather can provide the highest level of protection.

questions.question: Taking a turn too fast:
questions.answerA: Is acceptable as long as you stay under the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Is safer on a motorcycle than in a car.
questions.answerC: Is acceptable as long as no vehicles are near you.
questions.answerD: Can cause you to end up in another lane or leave the road.
questions.explanation: Taking a turn too fast is dangerous. If you cannot hold the turn, you may end up turning into another lane or even off of the road entirely. Use caution when taking a turn.

questions.question: When looking through a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn both your head and your shoulders to get a better look.
questions.answerB: Turn just your head, not your shoulders.
questions.answerC: Use only your mirrors.
questions.answerD: Only move your eyes, not your head.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: In general, riders should:
questions.answerA: Pick one lane position and always use it.
questions.answerB: Change lane positions frequently to prevent monotony.
questions.answerC: Choose a lane position that maximizes their space cushion.
questions.answerD: Never use the center lane position.
questions.explanation: Because road and traffic conditions are always changing, the safest lane position is also always changing. Choose the position that will maximize your space cushion and allow other drivers to see you most easily.

questions.question: How often should a motorcycle operator check their mirrors?
questions.answerA: Never
questions.answerB: Occasionally
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: More often than the amount time spent looking ahead
questions.explanation: It is recommended that you frequently check your mirrors to be aware of potential hazards behind you.

questions.question: You have been drinking alcohol. If you wait an hour for each drink before riding your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and riding.
questions.answerB: Your riding skills will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Side effects from the drinking may still remain.
questions.answerD: You will be okay as long as you ride slowly.
questions.explanation: On average, the body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. However, some alcohol may accumulate in the body even if a person consumes only one drink per hour. Their abilities and judgment can still be impaired.

questions.question: When you ride a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go by turning only your head. Keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance while turning. Your arms should be slightly bent any time you are holding the handgrips.

questions.question: Which of the following is a poor reason to sound your horn?
questions.answerA: A driver in the lane next to you is too close to the vehicle ahead of them.
questions.answerB: A parked car has a person in the driver’s seat.
questions.answerC: You want people to look at your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: You are passing someone who is in the street.
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to sound your horn before riding past a vehicle or pedestrian that may move into your lane. If you see a driver in an adjacent lane driving too closely to the vehicle ahead of them, you may assume that they want to pass and may cut in front of you to do so. If you see a person in the driver's seat of a parked car, or if you see a pedestrian or bicyclist in the street, it is a good idea to sound your horn as you pass.

questions.question: When going through a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stay in the same portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerB: Always stay in the left portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerC: Always stay in the right portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerD: Remember that the best path may not follow the curve of the road.
questions.explanation: Road and traffic conditions can change at any time. Always be prepared to change your lane position as appropriate no matter where you are on a roadway. The best path through a curve does not necessarily follow the curve of the road.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired while riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep going and hope to wake up.
questions.answerB: Ride faster.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Get off the road and rest.
questions.explanation: You should avoid riding if you are tired. When making a long trip, take rest breaks at least every two hours to reduce the risk of becoming fatigued.

questions.question: What is the primary psychoactive component in marijuana?
questions.answerA: THC
questions.answerB: TMJ
questions.answerC: MRT
questions.answerD: AAP
questions.explanation: The main psychoactive substance in marijuana is called tetrahydrocannabinol, or THC.

questions.question: Hearing protection is:
questions.answerA: Not needed if you wear a helmet.
questions.answerB: Needed in addition to a helmet.
questions.answerC: Only needed on windy days.
questions.answerD: Not needed if you are carrying a passenger.
questions.explanation: Exposure to engine and wind noise can damage your hearing, even if you are wearing a helmet. Hearing protection can guard against this while still allowing you to hear essential sounds like horns and sirens.

questions.question: When riding in curves, turning, or entering a highway, the best group formation is:
questions.answerA: Pairs.
questions.answerB: Single-file.
questions.answerC: Staggered.
questions.answerD: Passing.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is generally the best option when traveling in a group, riders should move into a single-file line through curves, through turns, and when entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: Riders who do not wear helmets while riding are ________ to die in a crash than riders who do wear helmets.
questions.answerA: Half as likely
questions.answerB: Twice as likely
questions.answerC: Three times as likely
questions.answerD: Just as likely
questions.explanation: No matter the speed, riders who are not wearing helmets are three times more likely to die from head injuries than riders who are wearing helmets at the time of a crash.

questions.question: When a group of riders is passing another vehicle on a two-lane road, the riders should:
questions.answerA: Pass in pairs.
questions.answerB: Pass in a staggered formation with several riders passing at the same time.
questions.answerC: Pass one at a time.
questions.answerD: Avoid passing.
questions.explanation: When a group of motorcyclists is passing another vehicle on a two-lane road, the riders should pass the vehicle one at a time. Each motorcyclist should complete their pass before the next rider's pass begins.

questions.question: If you think stopping your motorcycle will take longer than usual, you should:
questions.answerA: Lengthen your following distance.
questions.answerB: Shorten your following distance.
questions.answerC: Leave the road.
questions.answerD: Speed up.
questions.explanation: Lengthen your following distance when traveling on a slippery surface. If it will take longer than usual for your motorcycle to stop, open up to a longer following distance.

questions.question: When riding behind a car, you should ride:
questions.answerA: In any part of the lane.
questions.answerB: In the part of the lane closest to the shoulder.
questions.answerC: In the part of the lane that places your image in the car's rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: As close to the car as possible.
questions.explanation: When following a car, you should ride in a position that allows the driver to see you in their rearview mirror. Usually, that means riding in the center portion of the lane. Because most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than they check their side mirrors, being in this lane position increases the chance that they will see you.

questions.question: When making an ordinary stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerB: Use only the rear brake to save the front brake for special situations.
questions.answerC: Use only the front brake to save the rear brake for special situations.
questions.answerD: Sharply squeeze the front brake only.
questions.explanation: Develop the habit of using both brakes every time you slow or stop. If you need to stop quickly, it is best to apply both brakes. It will be easier to apply both brakes in a quick stop if you have already developed this habit.

questions.question: It is a good idea to wear reflective clothing:
questions.answerA: At night.
questions.answerB: During the day.
questions.answerC: At dusk.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Wearing reflective and brightly-colored clothing is always a good idea when riding a motorcycle. Crashes occur in broad daylight and at night, so it is best to wear highly visible clothing at any time of day.

questions.question: When following another vehicle as a beginning rider, you should:
questions.answerA: Maintain a minimum four-second following distance.
questions.answerB: Get as close to the other vehicle as possible.
questions.answerC: Never be concerned about your following distance.
questions.answerD: Always ride in the left portion of the lane so the driver can easily see you.
questions.explanation: A following distance of at least four seconds is recommended for beginning riders. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: When you are being passed, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Weave among the three portions of the lane as the vehicle passes.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally a good idea to ride in the center portion of your lane. Being on the side nearest the passing vehicle increases your risk of a collision. Being on the side farthest from the passing vehicle may prompt the other driver to merge back into your lane before it is safe.

questions.question: All of the following will lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, except:
questions.answerA: Remaining alert.
questions.answerB: Identifying hazards and prioritizing risks.
questions.answerC: Riding without a headlight.
questions.answerD: Maintaining a space cushion.
questions.explanation: To reduce your risk of being involved in a crash, you should remain alert and ready to react to any hazard. Identify hazards and decide the order in which you need to address the hazards. Always use your headlight to make yourself more visible and maintain an adequate space cushion around your motorcycle at all times.

questions.question: A person with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of ______ is considered legally intoxicated.
questions.answerA: 0.02 percent
questions.answerB: 0.04 percent
questions.answerC: 0.08 percent
questions.answerD: 0.1 percent
questions.explanation: In the state of Kentucky, a person with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent is considered legally intoxicated. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: You’ll have a better chance of avoiding serious injury if you wear all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: A DOT-approved helmet.
questions.answerB: Face or eye protection.
questions.answerC: Ear buds.
questions.answerD: Protective clothing.
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: Where is the throttle usually located?
questions.answerA: Near the left footrest
questions.answerB: Near the right footrest
questions.answerC: On the left handle grip
questions.answerD: On the right handle grip
questions.explanation: The throttle of a motorcycle is usually located on the right handle grip. Be sure to know where all of your motorcycle's controls are located before riding.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: You may ride on the shoulder.
questions.answerB: You may complete the pass in a no passing zone.
questions.answerC: You must start and complete the pass within a passing zone.
questions.answerD: You should sound your horn to get the other driver to slow down.
questions.explanation: All passing maneuvers must be completed within the posted speed limits and only in areas where passing is safe and legal.

questions.question: Usually, a good way to handle a tailgater is to:
questions.answerA: Move onto the shoulder to get out of their way.
questions.answerB: Speed up and put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerC: Ignore them.
questions.answerD: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.explanation: Usually, the best way to handle a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to follow you at a faster speed.

questions.question: To provide the best protection to the wearer, boots or shoes should:
questions.answerA: Be made of a soft material.
questions.answerB: Have long laces that are not tucked in.
questions.answerC: Cover the ankle and provide support.
questions.answerD: Have tall heels.
questions.explanation: For riding, choose boots or heavy shoes that are tall and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Heels should be low so that they won't catch on rough surfaces. Tuck in long laces so that they don't catch on the motorcycle's moving parts.

questions.question: A passenger on a motorcycle should:
questions.answerA: Mount the motorcycle before the engine starts.
questions.answerB: Mount the motorcycle after the engine starts.
questions.answerC: Sit as close to the rear of the motorcycle as possible.
questions.answerD: Hold onto the seat.
questions.explanation: Passengers should get on a motorcycle only after the engine has been started and the transmission is put in neutral. They should sit as far forward as possible without hindering the operator's control of the motorcycle and should hold onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: The front brake:
questions.answerA: Provides less than half of a motorcycle's braking power.
questions.answerB: Provides about 70 percent of a motorcycle's braking power.
questions.answerC: Should not be used unless the roadway is wet.
questions.answerD: Should be the only brake you use.
questions.explanation: The front brake is much more powerful than the rear one and provides at least 70 percent of a motorcycle's total stopping power. Use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: Where is the gearshift lever located?
questions.answerA: In front of the left footrest
questions.answerB: In front of the right footrest
questions.answerC: On the left handgrip
questions.answerD: On the right handgrip
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever is located in front of the left footrest and is operated with the left foot.

questions.question: A leather jacket:
questions.answerA: Can make a rider look cool.
questions.answerB: Is usually too warm to wear when riding.
questions.answerC: Provides protection in a crash.
questions.answerD: Should not be worn when riding.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should wear a long-sleeved jacket, ideally made of leather, when riding. In warm weather, a leather jacket can help protect you against dehydration. Many motorcycle jackets are designed to help keep you cool even when the weather is hot.
